What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course primarily gave a great deal of practice in literary analysis, as could be expected. Within that, we discussed genre, literary form, and construction at length. Though I don't speak or read Russian, questions of translation were also discussed occasionally, and were interesting. I also gained a broader knowledge of pre-revolutionary Russian authors, and some sense of the dialogues occurring between the authors.
I was exposed to the Russian canon.

Through this course, I learned an incredible amount about Russian literature theory and history, as there were a number of Slavic PhD students in the course who took our discussions to great heights. In fact, this was one of the first literature classes I have taken at Yale in which we have not strictly looked at the world of the text, but rather put each piece in some sort of broader context (which I found absolutely thrilling!). In addition, by the end of the course, I found myself asking questions about the autonomy and dimensionality of characters, their relationship to the narrator and the author, and whether the character itself is a modern concept. I found myself thinking about certain terminology and themes, and the time periods in which such terminology became a part of the literary discourse.
I got to dive into the world of Russian fiction, and developed a deeper and more nuanced understanding of the short form while I was at it.

The course was strong! It was a mix of graduate students and undergrads, which lent itself to slightly diverging interests for discussion. As an undergrad, it would have been more accessible at a few points with less emphasis on comparative literature outside of the syllabus, but those were rarely long discussions. There were many readings, which gave a good breadth of study, but could have been winnowed slightly in order to focus the class discussions more.

I liked how the readings were roughly chronological. It made the course cohesive. I personally didn't like how we only had one prompt for the midterm paper. I felt like I was much more excited about the final paper because I could pick from a wide range of options. I also felt like there were a few weeks when I was so stressed about doing all of the readings that I didn't have time to think that closely about any of the short stories I had read.

I think one of the biggest strengths of the course was the fact that Professor MacKay assigned each of the graduate students a week to present. As a number of them presented on authors and works to which they have devoted their graduate studies, it led to a number of really enriching discussions. I also think the syllabus and the way it was organized chronologically and thematically was brilliant. Perhaps one thing that could be improved is finding a way to create a more balanced discussion, in which the undergraduates feel better equipped to participate. Indeed, while I loved listening and absorbing the conversation, there were times when I felt the conversation was so removed from the world of the text that I was not sure any of my own comments were relevant. That being said, I learned a tremendous deal from listening!

There was a ton of reading, which was a strength and a weakness. Professor MacKay clearly loves the material and works to choose stories that will be generative in class. Every reading was fascinating, and seminar discussions were always rich. But it was a challenge to get through everything in time for class each week.

If you're considering comp lit courses, take it! MacKay is great and has a lot to say on the stories. The stories themselves are fascinating, and there isn't too much required by way of analysis - just a midterm and final paper, with weekly discussion posts.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! The class discussions were engaging, the weekly readings were enjoyable, and I learned a tremendous amount about Russian literature, history, culture, and theory.

Yes!! If you're interested in the material, take it! I learned so much and got to read so many interesting stories I would never have gotten to on my own. And Professor MacKay is a fabulous and passionate professor who makes sure everyone gets something out of class no matter how much or little background you're coming in with.
